text: Henry Osborne (August 21, 1751 – November 9, 1800) was a public official from Pennsylvania and Georgia. ==Biography== Born in Ireland, he emigrated to Pennsylvania in 1779, where he became a lawyer. He served as a judge advocate of the Pennsylvania militia during the American Revolution, but was removed from office in 1783 by the Supreme Executive Council for bigamy. After his removal from office, he moved to Georgia, buying land in Camden County. In 1786, he was elected to the Georgia Assembly and served until 1788. He was elected as a delegate to the Continental Congress in 1786 but did not attend. In 1787, he signed the charter of St. Marys and agreed to buy stock in the town.John H. Christian. The Founders of St. Marys. 1990. Henry Osborne served as a Commissioner of the United States for Indian Affairs in the Southern Department in the late 1780s. He negotiated talks between United States officials and the Creek Nation.American State Papers, 1789-1838. Indian Affairs, Vol. I. page 31. He became a Georgia Chief Justice in March 1787, and office he held until January 1789 when he became a judge of the Superior Court in the western district. Oborne was convicted by the Georgia senate in December 1791 of election fraud in the election of Anthony Wayne to the U.S. House of Representatives, and removed from his judgeship.Biographical Directory of the United States. His citizenship was restored under the Georgia constitution of 1798. Osborne died on St. Simons Island November 9, 1800. ==References== Category:People of Pennsylvania in the American Revolution Category:Georgia (U.S. state) state court judges Category:Members of the Georgia General Assembly Category:1751 births Category:1800 deaths Category:People from Camden County, Georgia Category:Impeached United States officials removed from office Category:18th-century American politicians
title: Henry Osborne (American politician)
